author: Standard125

25k+ comments a day, so apologies if this was linked prior. Interesting read from the VC world 

https://medium.com/sequoia-capital/coronavirus-the-black-swan-of-2020-7c72bdeb9753

If unfamiliar with Sequoia, they know a thing or two. 

From Wikipedia - Sequoia Capital has invested in over 250 companies since 1972, including Apple, Google, Oracle, PayPal, LinkedIn, Stripe, Bird[15], YouTube, Instagram, Yahoo! and WhatsApp.[16] The combined current public market value for these companies is over $1.4 trillion, equivalent to 22 percent of Nasdaq.[3] Its portfolio is mainly in financial services, healthcare, outsourcing, and technology.[13] As of 2017, they have exited in 68 initial public offerings and 203 acquisitions.[17]

author: TexanNewYorker
body:
Echoing other comments on here, I’d recommend other autism charities with better track records such as:
- Autistic Self Advocacy Network (ASAN)

- Autistic Women & Nonbinary Network (AWN)

- Self Advocates Becoming Empowered (SABE)


**Very little money donated to Autism Speaks goes toward helping autistic people and families.**

Only 1.6% of Autism Speaks’ budget goes
towards the “Family Service” grants that are the organization’s means of funding services. Autism Speaks spends 10x as much—16%—on fundraising. Although Autism Speaks has not prioritized services with a practical impact for families and individuals in its budget, its rates of executive pay are the highest in the autism world: some salaries exceed $500,000 a year.

**Autism Speaks talks about us without us.**

Autism Speaks has only 2 autistic people out of a total of 26 individuals on its Board of Directors. By contrast, 19 out of 26 board members represent major corporations, including current and former CEOs and senior executives of PayPal, Samsung, CBS, Goldman Sachs, White Castle, Viacom, American Express, FX Networks, Virgin Mobile, SiriusXM, and Sprint.

**Autism Speaks’ fundraising strategies promote fear, stigma, and prejudice against autistic people.**

Autism Speaks uses its platform and advertising budget to portray autism and autistic people as mysterious and frightening. Their fundraising tactics increase stigma and create barriers to the inclusion of autistic people in our communities.

author: vinlo
body:
>crypto seems to evolve shockingly little. 

I agree with everything you said up to this point. The general community may be a stagnant mass of cultish doomer idiots, but cryptocurrency as a technology has undergone some pretty drastic evolutions in the last 10 years. (Also keep in mind the typical person high-volatility, high-risk assets tend to attract...)

Its core functionality remains, but the Bitcoin of today is not the same as the Bitcoin released by Satoshi in 09.

&#x200B;

>but I even stopped doing that because quite frankly, it's a pain. It's  complicated, not cheap (once you account for the purchasing fees, and I have to freakin mention it in my taxes. 

Taxes are definitely a major point of friction for usage, at least in the US. But I still pay less for Bitcoin transactions than I do for Paypal transactions.

author: Raphalis
body:
If you are trying to learn more about investing in companies then I definitely think that you should be picking individual stocks! If not, then an ETF as some others have recommended would be fine.

But a stock I recommend is **PayPal**. It has an overall strong balance sheet in regards to assets-liabilities, their overall net income y/y increased by 26.2% (income statement) and they are actively utilizing cash flow for further acquisitions and investments which proved to be successful in 2019.

Other than the numbers (which are excellent if you look at their financial statements) I am very excited about their investments and acquisitions.

PayPal is the financial version of Facebook (but smaller). The parent company is not super cool and/or flashy but the revenue and bottom line net income is strong and its acquisitions are excellent.

Venmo processed over $29 billion in the fourth quarter alone which is a 56% y/y increase and its user base is consistently growing; it is not profitable yet, but the amount of growth that it has seen is great and is allowing PayPal to scale as it integrates its users; they have also landed deals with some companies in regards to using Venmo for purchases at stores. The fact that its functionality stems from it being a digital wallet is very innovative and convenient and is able to be utilized on a daily basis; this is excellent for retaining users (mostly young people are using it but now even older people are beginning to do so as well).

They also acquired Honey which is a means for PayPal to further acquire more users and to make them more relevant on a day-to-day basis as it is with Venmo; they saved users over $1 billion over the year and will see more users that can be integrated into Paypal's business model as time goes on (relatively new investment).

Acquiring a 70% stake in GoPay (a Chinese payment processing company) was monumental for the company as discussed in their earnings call. China processes trillions of dollars in transactions in online payments and PayPal is now the **FIRST** American company in China to provide online payment services!

Many people wonder about Plaid and how it will affect PayPal regarding competition, but PayPal has a stake in Plaid and is working with Visa to figure out ways to best utilize it; if their competition wins, so does PayPal.

Overall, PayPal has plenty of room for growth; their goal is to be relevant on a day-to-day basis and retain users and this will likely play out well for them EVEN when regarding a slow-down as we transition further away from cash. (Paypal revised guidance during the CV outbreak and slashed **only 1 percentage point of original estimates!!)**

The price has come down a lot and is looking more and more attractive.Best of luck!

That's a good question. I'm not sure how Twitch Prime gets monetized/paid on the streamer's side, same with Twitch Bits. I turned off Twitch donations so no one can accidentally donate to me. Everything is going through Tiltify.

I'll definitely donate all Prime subs and bits once they come through to my account or paypal or whatever. I just don't know how long it takes to turn into real money or how much it equates to.

author: insane_gravy
body:
> Why is it unacceptable to take grant money / tax incentives?

Because he has a habit of overpromising and underdelivering. We should not be incentivizing people with way more money than they could ever spend in a lifetime to deliver broken shit in exchange for money coming out of the public purse, especially when said money would otherwise go to real public works projects.

As for tax incentives, that's whole other discussion which is independent of Elon himself.

>He's kind of a maverick. That kind of guy tends to ruffle the feathers of the orthodox.

Then he can keep doing that with things like PayPal where the risk to the public doesn't come in the form of a self-guided flying bomb that can easily flatten 3 city blocks if something goes wrong. If he's gonna take money from the public purse he needs to be held to some bloody standards beyond the fawning praise that Reddit showers on this guy.

>Your first paragraph is opinion, your second is about how you don't think he has good ideas, and the last one is rumors and hearsay.

I work with launch vehicles for my day job. This isn't me spitballing, I've seen this kind of disregard for established standards first hand and heard it directly from people close to the actual problem. I've also been following the crew dragon explosion since it happened.

As for the whole bit about the hyperloop, if you don't believe me, just read the analysis by the damn experts who picked this harebrained idea apart. Hell, the youtuber Thunderf00t did a very thorough takedown of the technical issues if you want to hear it from a guy with a PhD. And again, I want to emphasize he is effectively sucking the oxygen out of the room when it comes to solving real issues, which prolongs how long the problems last.

And I haven't even gotten into how he treats his workers.

>I suspect that when public opinion went against the guy, you went along for the ride and you're not even sure why.

Guess again sugar. I remember when he was harassing independent engineers with lawsuit threats when they threatened to go public with evidence that his company was lying to the government. That was a decade ago.

>Would you say that you're anti-capitalist?

Bingo!
